mn85:58.1.eng: “In the same way, prince, there are these five factors that support meditation.
mn85:58.1.comm: Padhāna is literally to “fix” or “place” and hence to “try” or “strive”. Its core application is to apply oneself to spiritual practices, and hence in Buddhism it overlaps in meaning with “meditation”; a padhānasāla is a “meditation hall”. Here the five factors are qualities that are essential foundations for meditation.

mn85:58.3.pli: Idha, rājakumāra, bhikkhu saddho hoti; saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
mn85:58.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

mn85:58.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti;
mn85:58.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn85:58.5.pli: appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya;
mn85:58.5.eng: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

mn85:58.6.pli: asaṭho hoti amāyāvī yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu;
mn85:58.6.eng: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

mn85:58.7.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
mn85:58.7.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

mn85:58.8.pli: paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
mn85:58.8.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

mn85:58.9.eng: These are the five factors that support meditation.

mn85:59.1.pli: Imehi, rājakumāra, pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—
mn85:59.1.eng: When a mendicant with these five factors that support meditation has the Realized One as trainer, they could

mn85:59.2.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya satta vassāni.
mn85:59.2.eng: realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in seven years.

mn85:59.4.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—

mn85:59.5.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya chabbassāni …
mn85:59.5.eng: realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in six years,

mn85:59.10.eng: or as little as one year.

mn85:59.12.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—
mn85:59.12.eng: when a mendicant with these five factors that support meditation has the Realized One as trainer, they could

mn85:59.13.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya satta māsāni.
mn85:59.13.eng: realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in seven months,

mn85:59.15.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—

mn85:59.16.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—

mn85:59.17.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya cha māsāni …

mn85:59.25.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—

mn85:59.26.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—

mn85:59.27.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya satta rattindivāni.

mn85:59.29.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno—

mn85:59.30.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—

mn85:59.31.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya cha rattindivāni …

mn85:59.36.eng: or as little as one day.

mn85:59.38.pli: Imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu tathāgataṃ vināyakaṃ labhamāno sāyamanusiṭṭho pāto visesaṃ adhigamissati, pātamanusiṭṭho sāyaṃ visesaṃ adhigamissatī”ti.
mn85:59.38.eng: when a mendicant with these five factors that support meditation has the Realized One as trainer, they could be instructed at dusk and achieve distinction at daybreak, or be instructed at daybreak and achieve distinction at dusk.”

mn85:60.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bodhi rājakumāro bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn85:60.1.eng: When he had spoken, Prince Bodhi said to the Buddha,

mn85:60.2.pli: “aho buddho, aho dhammo, aho dhammassa svākkhātatā.
mn85:60.2.eng: “Oh, the Buddha! Oh, the teaching! Oh, how well explained is the teaching!

mn85:60.3.pli: Yatra hi nāma sāyamanusiṭṭho pāto visesaṃ adhigamissati, pātamanusiṭṭho sāyaṃ visesaṃ adhigamissatī”ti.
mn85:60.3.eng: For someone could be instructed at dusk and achieve distinction at daybreak, or be instructed at daybreak and achieve distinction at dusk.”

mn85:61.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sañjikāputto māṇavo bodhiṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca:
mn85:61.1.eng: When he said this, Sañjikāputta said to Prince Bodhi,

mn85:61.2.eng: “Though the worthy Bodhi speaks like this,

mn85:61.3.pli: ‘aho buddho, aho dhammo, aho dhammassa svākkhātatā’ti ca vadeti;

mn85:61.4.pli: atha ca pana na taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañcā”ti.
mn85:61.4.eng: you don’t go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.”

mn85:61.5.pli: “Mā hevaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, avaca; mā hevaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, avaca.
mn85:61.5.eng: “Don’t say that, dear Sañjikāputta, don’t say that!

mn85:61.6.pli: Sammukhā metaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, ayyāya sutaṃ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ”.
mn85:61.6.eng: I have heard and learned this in the presence of my lady mother.
mn85:61.6.comm: His “lady mother” (ayyā), as noted above, was Queen Vāsuladattā, daughter of Pajjota and wife of Udena. | This is the only place in the Pali canon where the idiom “heard and learned this in the presence” is applied to anyone other than the Buddha.

mn85:61.7.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
mn85:61.7.eng: This one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

mn85:61.8.pli: Atha kho me ayyā kucchimatī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho me ayyā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn85:61.8.eng: Then my pregnant lady mother went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn85:61.9.pli: ‘yo me ayaṃ, bhante, kucchigato kumārako vā kumārikā vā so bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn85:61.9.eng: ‘Sir, the prince or princess in my womb goes for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn85:61.10.pli: Upāsakaṃ taṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan’ti.
mn85:61.10.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember them as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.’

mn85:61.11.pli: Ekamidaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, samayaṃ bhagavā idheva bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
mn85:61.11.eng: Another time the Buddha was staying here in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

mn85:61.12.pli: Atha kho maṃ dhāti aṅkena haritvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho maṃ dhāti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn85:61.12.eng: Then my nursemaid, carrying me on her hip, went to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

mn85:61.13.pli: ‘ayaṃ, bhante, bodhi rājakumāro bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn85:61.13.eng: ‘Sir, this Prince Bodhi goes for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn85:61.14.pli: Upāsakaṃ taṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan’ti.
mn85:61.14.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember him as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.’

mn85:61.15.pli: Esāhaṃ, samma sañjikāputta, tatiyakampi bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn85:61.15.eng: Now for a third time I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn85:61.16.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn85:61.16.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
